He is requesting a loan as he really wishes to have maintenance work done on his motorcycle taxi. He hopes that he will thereby be able to provide a safer service and have more work to support his household.

loans.use: to service his motorcycle and buy spare parts.

loans.name: Nimol's Group

texts.en:
Nimol is 24 years old and a citizen in a rural area of the Moung Russey district of Battambang province, Cambodia. She has one daughter who is dependent on her and too young for schooling. To tackle the financial difficulty, Nimol and her husband have done rice-cropping on six hectares of farmland for several years as the main source of their famiily's income. To increase their income, this couple also runs a small grocery store at home. Both businesses have provided her about 20,000 KHR per day. She has saved about 14,000 KHR each day after daily expenses. However, a lack of water supply is still the main challenge for her paddy business.

Nimol’s group consists of five members who live in the same village. She and two of her fellow group members are in their second-cycle microloan, while the remaining two members are first-time borrowers with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund. Nimol feels empowered that she can relieve her family's burden and improve their livelihood after the past loans were paid back with success. Now she is leading her group to seek a loan. Nimol, who is the leader, will use her portion to buy fertilizer for her farmland and split a portion of it to buy more grocery items for reselling. She hopes her crop yield will become more productive and profitable so as to make a better living for her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her farmland

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is married and has three children. Virginia is 47 years old and resides at Campo 5, Ramon Magsaysay. Virginia owns and operates farmland, planting and harvesting rice for sale to earn a living, and she's been 25 years in this business. Each month, she earns 7,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) doing this type of business. 

She requested a loan of 7,000 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure. In 2010, Virginia joined GDMPC. In the future, Virginia wants to make improvements to her house and to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Luz Marina

texts.es:
La socia se sigue dedicando al negocio de crianza de animales y ganados,la socia cria cuyes,gallinas y chanchos,la socia los hace crecer y engordra y luego los vende en los diferentes mercados y tambien saca leche de los ganados y los vende,la socia se dedica a estos negocios 6 años y le va muy bien,el sueño de la socia es tener un local donde pueda vender los animales.La socia solicita el credito para comprar alimentos para los animales y tambien para comprar pollos,cuyes y chanchos.

La socia está agradecida por el apoyo que se otorgará a ella y también se ha comprometido a ser disciplinados en hacer los pagos.
texts.en: Luz Marina continues to work on her business of raising animals and cattle.  She raises guinea pigs, chickens, and pigs.  She makes them grow large and then sells them at different markets.  She also sells the milk of her cattle.  She has been doing this for the last six years and it is going very well for her.  Her dream is to have her own store where she can sell the animals.  She is seeking a loan to purchase animal feed as well as guinea pigs, chickens, and pigs.  She is grateful for the support and promises to be disciplined in her payments.

loans.use: to purchase animal feed and chickens, guinea pigs, and pigs.

loans.name: Mary Grace

texts.en:
This is Mary Grace. She previously accessed an 20,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase additional stock of supplies and materials needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education, and in their personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan to buy additional stock of supplies, materials and medicines needed in her business. The more items displayed at the store, the better sales and profits will be. Her profits from business will definitely help to sustain her family’s daily needs and her children’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Mary Grace dreams of expanding her business in the coming years and hopes to give her family a good future. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* where she shares stories of her work with other members every week, and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional stock of supplies, materials and medicines needed in her business

loans.name: Savy's Group

texts.en:
Savy, 34, lives in a rural village of the Thmor Koul district of Battambang province, Cambodia. She has four children, three of whom are dependent on her and still in school. She is a rice farmer and grows rice on two hectares of farmland. Having been in this business for several years, she is able to earn about 15,000 KHR per day and save about 7,000 KHR of that after deducting daily expenses. Low crop yield is the main challenge for her paddy field.

Savy has been with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund, for one cycle. She fully repaid the first loan, which has helped her support her family’s living condition. Now, she and her group member are asking for a loan of 500,000 KHR and 100,000 KHR, respectively. As the leader, Savy will use her portion to buy fertilizers and rice seeds for her farmland. She hopes this loan will help her to increase her income to make a good quality of living for her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and rice seeds for her farmland.

loans.name: Nikolin

texts.en:
Nikolin is a 44-year-old man who was remarried after his first wife passed away suddenly, leaving him with three very young children. Now he is expecting another child soon. 

Being the only one to bring an income home, it has been very difficult for him, Nikolin claims. “Not only I had to care for my family financially all those years, but lately emotionally too. My kids have been grieving ever since and at times I don’t know what else to do for them to fade away their pain. I find myself lost as well,” he continued saying, wiping away his tears.

When the children’s mother passed away, Nikolin started his livestock business in order to look after them instead of doing a traditional job as he had done up to that time. Since the business has been doing well, and he has been happy with the income, Nikolin now wants to repair the stable. This is why he is requesting a loan this time.

Nikolin remains positive and hopes he will be supported by lenders.

loans.use: To repair an existing stable.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: Emmanuel is 32 years old. He is married to a business woman. They have two children between the ages of 5 months and 5 years. He owns a bar where he sells different items such as beer and soda. He wants the loan to add more beers and sodas to the stock for sale. The profits from the business will be used for savings.

loans.use: To buy more beers and sodas for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to maintain his motorcycle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and run two Fresh Life toilets.

loans.name: Chhoen's Group

texts.en:
Chhoen is a resident of a rural village in the Thmor Koul district of Battambang province, Cambodia. She is 49 years old and married with one son. She has earned a living through farming rice on four-hectares of farmland for 33 years. She is able to earn about 20,000 KHR per day and save around 10,000 KHR each day after offsetting daily expenses. The shortage of water for her paddy is the main challenge.

Chhoen has been with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund, for two cycles and successfully paid back her loans. The other members have been with VisionFund for one or two cycles. She has wisely used the past loans to better support her family with sufficient food. Now, she is leading her group of three to request a loan. Chhoen is going to use her portion to buy fertilizer for her farmland. She hopes her crop yield will become more profitable and productive in order to improve her family's rural living conditions..

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her farm

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en:
Anthony is an electrician from the Mukuru informal settlement of Nairobi. Along with his wife and three children, he runs a small shop in the community. Anthony also has land north of the city on which he runs a potato farm. 

Anthony is interested in running a Fresh Life toilet business because he has heard other Fresh Life operators sing its praises. He often sees businesses start and subsequently flounder very rapidly, but believes that with the ongoing business support and insurance from Fresh Life, this venture will not fail. Anthony’s ultimate goal with this business is to make enough profits to further his education at the university level.

loans.use: To purchase and run Fresh Life toilets.

loans.name: Sinoun's Group

texts.en:
Sinoun is a 57-year-old married mother of three children, one of whom is dependent on her and still in school. She lives in a village in Battambang province’s Moung Russey district of Cambodia. To support the family, she has been engaged in farming rice on 2.5 hectares of farmland for 28 years while her husband works as a solider. Sinoun earns approximately 18,000 KHR per day and saves about 10,000 KHR each day after deducting daily expenses. Drought is the main challenge for her paddy-field business. 

She has been with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund, for four loan cycles and the other member has been with VisionFund for three cycles. She completely repaid the past loans, which have enabled her to relieve her family’s burden and improve their livelihood. Now, she is leading her group to request a loan. Sinoun, who is the leader, will use her portion to buy rice seeds, fertilizer and pesticide for her farm and to pay for labor fees. She hopes this loan will enable her crop yield to become more profitable in order to make a better living and keep her child in school.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds, fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Marciana

texts.en:
This is Marciana. She previously accessed a 9,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and other materials needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan to buy additional supplies of raw materials needed in her business. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to provide her family’s daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Marciana hopes her business grows and dreams of being able to give her family a good future through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the study of the Word of God.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for raw materials like fabric and thread

loans.name: Sayoeng

texts.en:
Sayoeng is aged 45 years and married with four children, three of whom are dependent on her and help the family’s business. She lives in a rural village of the Moung Russey district of Battambang province, Cambodia. She has been growing rice on 3 hectares of farmland and corn on 2 hectares of farmland as the main source of the family’s income. She has been in this business for 12 years to support the family. She is able to earn about 30,000 KHR per day and manages to save about 20,000 KHR each day after offsetting expenses for future needs. Lack of water supply for supporting the rice paddy is the main challenge.

This is the second microloan for Sayoeng with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund. She successfully paid back the past loan which has supported her family's living conditions. Now she is requesting a loan with VisionFund of 4,000,000 KHR. With this loan, she is going to buy fertilizer and seeds for her farmland. She hopes this loan will enable her to increase her income from the rice paddy so as to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds for her farmland

loans.name: Antoinette

texts.en: Antoinette is 39 years old. She is married to a businessman and they have three children. She sells goats and has spent 17 years in similar businesses. The profits from the business will be saved for the future of her business.

loans.use: To buy more goats to sell

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.es: La socia es la señora Marcelina, madre de 3 hijos, ella continúa con su actividad económica de elaboración y comercialización de queso, pero adicionalmente la socia esta incursionando en el oficio de corte y confección, elaborando prendas de vestir  en general y disfraces. Marcelina en esta oportunidad está solicitando el préstamo para capitalizar su actividad alternativa de costura y comprar telas, hilos y accesorios para la confección de sus disfraces. Marcelina está muy agradecida con la ayuda de KIVA, por ayudarla a fortalecer su actividad económica la cual le permite ofrecer una mejor calidad de vida a su familia. La socia pertenece al banco comunal “KANCHARY”; de la ciudad del Cusco – Perú.
texts.en:
Marcelina, who has three children, continues in her business of making and selling cheese, but the member has also branched out to become a seamstress, making general clothing and costumes.  On this occasion, Marcelina is requesting a loan for her sewing business, to buy fabric, thread and sewing accessories to make costumes.

Marcelina is very grateful for the KIVA help, since it has strengthened her business activity, allowing her to give her family a better quality of life.  She belongs to the communal bank "KANCHARY" in Cusco, Perú.

loans.use: To buy fabric, thread and accessories to make costumes.

loans.name: Rosario

texts.es: La socia es la señora Rosario, ella continúa con su actividad económica de comercialización de artesanías, principalmente elementos de joyería como collares, pulseras, aretes etc.. Rosario en esta oportunidad está solicitando el préstamo para capitalizar su actividad y comprar las joyas y accesorios en plata que mas demanda tiene. Rosario está muy agradecida con la ayuda de KIVA, por ayudarla a fortalecer su actividad económica la cual le permite ofrecer una mejor calidad de vida a su familia. La socia pertenece al banco comunal “KANCHARY”; de la ciudad del Cusco – Perú.
texts.en:
The member, Rosario, continues with her craft business, mainly jewelry items such as necklaces, bracelets, earrings, etc.  On this occasion, Rosario is requesting a loan for business capital to buy silver jewelry and accessories that are in highest demand.

Rosario is very grateful for the KIVA help, which has strengthened her business, allowing her to give her family a better quality of life.  The member belongs to the communal bank "KANCHARY" in Cusco, Perú.

loans.use: To buy silver jewelry and accessories.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.es:
La socia es la señora Concepción, 57 años de edad, soltera y con 4 hijos, 2 de ellos dependientes de ella, Concepción  se dedica  al negocio del restaurante, y es con esta actividad que sacó adelante a todos sus hijos.
Concepción está solicitando el préstamo para invertirlo en capitalizar su restaurante  y comprar insumos como arroz, fideos, verduras, carnes y granos para la producción de su restaurante. Concepción está muy agradecida con la ayuda de KIVA, para fortalecer su actividad económica la cual le permite ofrecer una mejor calidad de vida a su familia. La socia pertenece al banco comunal “KANCHARY”; de la ciudad del Cusco – Perú.
texts.en:
This member, Concepción, is 57, single and has four children, two of which are independent.  Concepción has a restaurant business which has allowed her to support her children.

Concepción is requesting a loan to capitalize her restaurant and buy supplies such as rice, noodles, vegetables, meat and grains to make meals.  She is very grateful for the KIVA help which has strengthened her business, allowing her to give her family a better quality of life.  The member belongs to the communal bank "KANCHARY" in Cusco, Perú.

loans.use: To buy supplies such as rice, noodles, vegetables, meat and grains.

loans.name: Yehia

texts.en:
Yehia is a 45-year-old married man and father of five children. He has been preparing and selling sweets for 18 years. He is well known in the region with his special taste Arabic sweets and delights. Yehia is working hard on improving his business as much as he can. That's why he moved to a wider factory and shop four months ago, which attracted more customers and increased his sales.

To keep on expanding his business, Yehia is applying for a loan from Kiva's partner Al Majmoua, which he will use to buy a special Petit Four mixer that will help him start manufacturing foreign sweets. Yehia is working hard at diversifying his products to keep his customers satisfied.

This is Yehia's ninth cycle as an Al Majmoua borrower with an excellent history in paying back his loans.  He says that all of his previous loans were invested in expanding his business by increasing his machinery, tools and raw materials, which led to improving both his social and financial situation, in addition to his image in the region.

loans.use: To buy a special sweets mixer

loans.name: Cheat

texts.en:
Cheat is a citizen from a rural village in Battambang province’s Moung Russey district of Cambodia. She is 40 years old and married with four children, three of whom are dependent on her and too young for school. To make a living, she has been growing rice on eight hectares of farmland for 20 years and supplementing her family’s income by growing pineapples to support the family. She is able to earn about 30,000 KHR per day and save about 20,000 KHR each day after offsetting daily expenses. Insufficient water supply for her paddy is still the main challenge.

This is the first micro loan for Cheat with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund. She is applying for a loan of 2,000,000 KHR. She is going to use this loan to buy fertilizer for her farmland. She hopes this loan will enable her to increase more income from her crop yield to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Garik

texts.en:
Garik is a young farmer from Yeghegnadzor town in the Vayots Dzor region. Garik breeds cows, pigs, hens, and rabbits and grows fruit trees. Currently, Garik keeps the livestock in an old barn, which does not allow him to create the necessary conditions for the livestock, especially during the cold winter season. So, Garik wants to construct a new barn, for which he needs sufficient funds. With the help of this loan, he plans to purchase construction materials for the barn. Garik also plans to purchase grass to feed the cows and sawdust to feed the hens. 

Garik lives with his wife, two-year-old daughter, brother and parents. Stable development of agriculture is important for him to earn enough income and sustain the family.

loans.use: to buy livestock feed and construction materials for the barn

loans.name: Coumba

texts.fr: Madame Coumba est une femme divorcée qui vit dans une des localités sénégalaises. Elle capitalise une expérience de plus de 2 ans dans le secteur du commerce et pratique l’activité de restauratrice. Les revenus que lui procure son activité lui permettent de prendre en charge les frais de scolarité de ses enfants, de meme les factures d’électricité, le salaire de la domestique et une participation à la dépense quotidienne. Elle consacre 12 heures de temps de la journée à son activité. Elle est membre dans l’un des guichets de l’UIMCEC et sollicite un crédit de 200 000 frs. Une partie du crédit est  prévu pour la réfection de sa gargote  et l’autre partie sera destinée à l’achat de matériels et d’ustensiles qu’elle utilise dans l’exercice de son activité. Son objectif  est d’améliorer le cadre de son local pour mieux attirer la clientèle de meme que la qualité  des repas qu’elle offre a sa clientèle. L’augmentation de ses bénéfices lui permettra de mieux supporter ses charges familiales, de d’épargner de l’argent et d’améliorer les conditions alimentaires de sa famille.
texts.en:
Coumba is a divorced woman who lives in a Senegalese village. She has over 2 years experience in the retail sector as a restaurateur. The income generated by her business enables her to take care of her children's education expenses, pay the electricity bills and the salary of the domestic worker, and contribute to the daily expenses. She spends 12 hours a day at work.

Coumba is a member of a UIMCEC branch and is requesting a loan of 200 000 francs, part of which will be used to repair her small restaurant and part of which will go towards buying the kitchen equipment and utensils that she uses for her business. Her aim is to improve the setting of her business in order to draw in more customers, and to improve the quality of the meals that she offers to her clientèle. An increase in her profits would enable her to better manage her family expenses, build up her savings and improve her family's food conditions.

loans.use: to repair her small restaurant and buy kitchen utensils.

loans.name: Fatima

texts.fr: Madame Fatima est une femme mariée. Elle habite dans une des localités sénégalaises. Elle s’active depuis plus de 5 ans dans le secteur de la couture. Elle confectionne et vend des habits prêts a porter. Elle consacre 11 heures de temps de la journée à son activité. Les profits qui lui sont générés lui permettent de payer le loyer et ses employeurs, mais aussi de supporter la dépense quotidienne de sa famille. Elle est sociétaire dans l’un des guichets de l’UIMCEC et sollicite un crédit de 500 000 frs prévu pour l’achat d’une machine a coudre plus performante  en vue de mieux rentabiliser son activité. Son ambition est d’augmenter dans l’avenir le nombre de ses machines ainsi que le nombre de ses employés.
texts.en:
Fatima is a married woman. She lives in a Senegalese village. She has been working in the sewing sector for over 5 years. She makes and sells ready-to-wear clothing. She spends 11 hours a day at work. The profits generated by her business allow her to pay the rent and her employees, and also to take care of her family's daily expenses.

Fatima is a member of a UIMCEC branch and is requesting a loan of 500 000 francs which will be used to buy a more high-performance sewing machine in order to make her business more profitable. Her aim is to eventually increase the number of machines she owns and people she employs.

loans.use: to buy a sewing machine.

loans.name: Akouvi

texts.fr: Avec ce premier prêt que madame Akouvi sollicite auprès de WAGES, elle va s’acheter de la farine de blé, des bidon d’huile et des sacs de sucre. Ces matières premières dont elle a besoin, lui servira à préparer des beignets. Activité qu’elle mène depuis 2002 à domicile, madame Akouvi âgée de 37ans, mère de 02 enfants (12 et 05ans) tous scolarisés a pour mari un enseignant. Avec les bénéfices de son activité, elle assurer l’autosuffisance alimentaire de la famille et le renforcement de l’activité.
texts.en: Akouvi is requesting her first loan from WAGES in order to buy wheat flour, cans of oil and bags of sugar. These are the primary ingredients that she needs to make doughnuts. Akouvi has been running her home-based business since 2002. She is 37 years old, married to a teacher and the mother of 2 children, aged 5 and 12, who both go to school. She will use the profits from her business to ensure that her family is self-sufficient in food and to strengthen her business.

loans.use: to buy wheat flour, cans of oil and bags of sugar.

loans.name: Affi

texts.fr: Mariée à un comptable et mère d’01 enfant de 06ans qui va à l’école, madame Affi âgée de 31ans est revendeuse de profession. Elle vend des bazins et autres tissus depuis 2008 à domicile et de façon ambulante à ses clients. Les demandes deviennent de plus en plus importantes et n’arrivant pas à satisfaire ses clients, elle sollicite de WAGES un second prêt pour acheter des pagnes et d’autres tissus pour dames afin de garder sa clientèle. Elle veut développer son activité par l’ouverture d’une boutique et assurer au coté de son mari les charges du foyer.
texts.en: Married to an accountant and mother to a 6-year-old child who attends school, Affi is 31 years old and a retailer. She has been selling damask and other fabrics to her customers since 2008, both at home and on the street. The demand is increasing more and more and, as she is not able to satisfy her customers, she is requesting a second loan from WAGES in order to buy pagnes (highly colourful and decorative West African cloth) and other fabrics for women's clothing, so that she can keep her clientèle. She would like to expand her business by opening a shop and to take care of the household expenses, together with her husband.

loans.use: to buy damask and other fabrics.

loans.name: Komi Isaac

texts.fr: Komi Isaac est un jeune homme de 38ans. Il est marié et papa de 02 enfants. Il est revendeur de profession. Sa boutique qu’il a ouvert dans un quartier  de la place lui permet de revendre des vêtements qu’il s’approvisionne chez les grossistes  venant de la CHINE. Il est à son premier prêt à WAGES et il lui servira à acheter des habits pour revendre aux clients. Comme perspectives d’avenir, il voudrait renforcer son activité et assurer l’épanouissement de la famille.
texts.en: Komi Isaac is a young, 38-year-old man. He is married and father to 2 children. He is a retailer. His shop, which he opened in a local district, enables him to sells clothing which he buys from Chinese wholesalers. This is his first loan from WAGES and it will be used to buy clothing for resale to his customers. His long term plans are to strengthen his business and to ensure that his family flourishes.

loans.use: to buy clothing.

loans.name: Babacar

texts.fr: Monsieur Babacar est un couturier marié qui évolue dans le secteur depuis plus de 10 ans. Il  s’active dans  la confection et la vente de prêts à porter. Il consacre 11 heures de temps à son activité. Il est membre d’un des guichets de l’UIMCEC. Il sollicite un crédit de 500 000 frs prévu pour l’achat de tissus et garnitures destinés  a confectionner des habits a revendre a l’occasion de la fête de Tabaski. L’accroissement de ses revenus lui permettra de mieux supporter ses charges (loyer, électricité, salaires personnel, dépense quotidienne), d’épargner et d’améliorer les conditions alimentaires de sa famille. Babacar souhaite agrandir son atelier dans le futur pour  mieux développer son activité.
texts.en: Babacar is a married tailor who has been in his line of work for over 10 years. He makes and sells ready-to-wear clothing. He spends 11 hours a day working. He is a member of a UIMCEC branch and is requesting a loan of 500 000 francs so that he can buy fabrics and trimmings with which to make clothing to sell for the Tabaski festival. An increase in his income would allow him to better cover his expenses (rent, electricity, salaries, daily expenses), to build savings and to improve his family's food conditions. Babacar would eventually like to expand his workshop in order to better develop his business.

loans.use: to buy fabric with which to make clothing for resale.

loans.name: Lamie

texts.en:
Lamie is 32 years old and single. She works very hard to provide for her family.

Lamie runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell in her general store. She has been in this business for 20 years and sells a variety of items such as canned goods, plastic bags, and spices. 

In the future, Lamie would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase items to sell in her general store

loans.name: Mazide Ismail

texts.en:
Mazide  is a 40-year-old  businessman who lives in Juba.  He is married, with 4 children between the ages of 3 and 12.  All of them are in school.

Mazide runs a general store, has been in business for 3 years, and has no employees. He heard about Finance Sudan through promotions by the loan officers.

He is taking a loan of 2000sdg to purchase groundnuts, and many other items.  He has no source of income other than this business.

In 5 years, Mazide would like to expand his business and open other branches.  His major challenges include high market prices.

Mazide says he is happy for the loans given by Finance Sudan through the help of  Kiva.

loans.use: to buy more items like groundnuts.

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en: Patricia is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a bakery business in the Philippines. She is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy more ingredients for her bakery. Patricia has been in this business for 15 years. She earns additional income from raising pigs and farming rice. Patricia has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She hopes to save money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional ingredients for her bakery

loans.name: Dada Alfred

texts.en:
Dada is a 35-year-old businessman who lives in Juba. He is married and has 3 children between the ages of 3 and 9. All of them go to school.
Dada runs a general store, and has been in business for 4 years. He doesn't have any employees. He heard about Finance Sudan through promotions by loan officers. He is taking a loan of 3000 SDG to purchase dry fish, sugar, oil, and many other items. This business is Dada's only source of income.

In 5 years Dada would like to expand his business and open other branches. His major challenge is the high cost of transportation.

Dada says he is happy for the loans given by Finance Sudan through the help of Kiva.

loans.use: buy more sugar, dry fish, oil, etc.
